critique:
The document aims to instill a sense of duty, resilience, and loyalty among members of the armed forces. The primary emotions the President wants to elicit are likely a mix of determination (joy/pride in service), resolve (minimizing fear), and commitment (reducing any inclination towards disgust or surrender). Surprise is not a major factor. Initial assessment:
Joy: 7 (Pride in service, dedication to principles)
Sadness: 2 (Acknowledging potential for capture/sacrifice, but not dwelling on it)
Anger: 3 (Directed at the enemy, but not explicitly expressed)
Fear: 3 (Acknowledging danger, but emphasizing resistance)
Disgust: 1 (Minimizing any thought of surrender or collaboration)
Surprise: 1 (No element of surprise)

Revised assessment:
Joy: 8 (Increased emphasis on pride and dedication)
Sadness: 1 (Further reduction, focusing on resilience)
Anger: 2 (Subtle, more about resolve than rage)
Fear: 2 (Focus on overcoming fear through training and commitment)
Disgust: 1 (Maintaining minimal consideration of negative emotions)
Surprise: 1 (No change)
